dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, you know, we always talk about climate change, right? But this article really broadens the scope for me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, you know, we always talk about climate change, right? But this article really broadens the scope for me.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely, Host_A. It's like, uh, it's not *just* about the climate, is it? We're talking biodiversity, soil, air, oceans... all these interconnected systems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely, Host A. It's like, uh, it's not just about the climate, is it? We're talking biodiversity, soil, air, oceans... all these interconnected systems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While few dispute the need to combat climate change, the Earths biodiversity, soil, air, oceans, and freshwater systems are also increasingly threatened.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the idea that these natural systems, like, interact with the climate and basically determine, uh, our entire planetary conditions. And if they keep deteriorating...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the idea that these natural systems, like, interact with the climate and basically determine, uh, our entire planetary conditions. And if they keep deteriorating...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Together, these natural systems interact with the climate and determine the environmental conditions for the entire planet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. I mean, millions of lives, livelihoods at risk, especially in the Global South. And for the first time, policymakers and scientists are really having to consider, like, how much human activity is messing with the benign conditions that let us flourish for ten thousand years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. I mean, millions of lives, livelihoods at risk, especially in the Global South. And for the first time, policymakers and scientists are really having to consider, like, how much human activity is messing with the benign conditions that let us flourish for ten thousand years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Should those conditions continue deteriorating, the lives and livelihoods of millions of people, especially in the Global South, will be at risk. This is why, for the first time in history, policymakers and the science community must consider the extent to which man-made forces are threatening the benign conditions that have allowed societies to flourish over the last 10,000 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's a pretty stark warning. They even say we're on the cusp of a 'dangerous planetary shift' where Earth's systems will stop absorbing our damage and actually start intensifying it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a pretty stark warning. They even say we're on the cusp of a dangerous planetary shift where Earth's systems will stop absorbing our damage and actually start intensifying it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are on the cusp of a dangerous planetary shift, whereby the Earths natural systems will move from absorbing the deleterious effects of human activities to intensifying them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And get this: even phasing out fossil fuels, while totally necessary, won't be enough to hit the Paris Agreement targets. We need to actively safeguard *all* natural systems, you know, from polar regions to marine environments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And get this: even phasing out fossil fuels, while totally necessary, won't be enough to hit the Paris Agreement targets. We need to actively safeguard all natural systems, you know, from polar regions to marine environments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Worse, we can already say with certainty that phasing out fossil fuels, while necessary, will not be enough to meet the Paris agreements target of keeping global warming well below 2Â°C relative to pre-industrial levels. We also will need to safeguard the health and functionality of natural systems, from polar regions and forests to grasslands and marine environments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we need, like, shared targets based on science for the *entire* Earth system? That's a huge undertaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we need, like, shared targets based on science for the entire Earth system? That's a huge undertaking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To do that, we will need shared targets based on scientifically defined guardrails for the entire Earth system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But, you know, some companies and cities are actually starting to get it. Like after the Amazon fires, 150 institutional investors, with like, $17 trillion, called for anti-deforestation measures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But, you know, some companies and cities are actually starting to get it. Like after the Amazon fires, one hundred fifty institutional investors, with like, seventeen trillion dollars, called for anti-deforestation measures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, in the wake of this years devastating fires in the Amazon basin, 230 institutional investors, representing $16.2 trillion in assets under management, called on companies with supply chains connected to these vulnerable ecosystems to implement new anti-deforestation measures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a good start. But the article points out that while Paris has quantitative targets for climate, there's a real lack of specific international targets for, um, the *rest* of the global commons.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a good start. But the article points out that while Paris has quantitative targets for climate, there's a real lack of specific international targets for, um, the rest of the global commons.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, while the Paris agreement establishes quantitative science-based targets for tackling climate change, specific international targets for preserving the rest of the global commons are scarce, and there are very few mechanisms for translating such benchmarks into meaningful standards for different countries, companies, and cities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! And not many mechanisms to translate those benchmarks for individual countries or companies. Which is where the Earth Commission comes in, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! And not many mechanisms to translate those benchmarks for individual countries or companies. Which is where the Earth Commission comes in, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: there are very few mechanisms for translating such benchmarks into meaningful standards for different countries, companies, and cities. To make up for this shortfall, we are co-chairing the first Earth Commission, which will define science-based targets for maintaining a stable and resilient planet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, yes! [interrupts] The second Earth Commission. So, they're defining science-based targets for a stable planet?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, yes! The second Earth Commission. So, they're defining science-based targets for a stable planet?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To make up for this shortfall, we are co-chairing the first Earth Commission, which will define science-based targets for maintaining a stable and resilient planet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. It's like twenty internationally recognized natural and social scientists from all over the world. They're going to compile a high-level synthesis of knowledge on how the planet's stability works, and also, uh, what social transformations are needed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. It's like twenty internationally recognized natural and social scientists from all over the world. They're going to compile a high-level synthesis of knowledge on how the planet's stability works, and also, uh, what social transformations are needed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the Earth Commission brings together some 20 internationally recognized natural and social scientists from around the world. ... It will also provide a scientific synthesis of the social transformations required to sustain the development of human societies within a safe planetary operating space.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And those findings then get used by something called the Science Based Targets Network, or SBTN, to set practical goals for companies and cities, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And those findings then get used by something called the Science Based Targets Network, or S B T N, to set practical goals for companies and cities, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The commissions work will provide the evidence needed to enable another coalition member, the Science Based Targets Network, to carry out its work. The SBTN, which comprises leading environmental institutions and NGOs, will set specific, achievable goals for companies and eventually cities, helping them to reduce their environmental impact and start to restore natural systems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep. The SBTN will take those big picture ideas and make them specific, achievable goals to reduce environmental impact and restore natural systems. The goal, actually, is to make this the new standard practice for *all* businesses and cities by 2025.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep. The S B T N will take those big picture ideas and make them specific, achievable goals to reduce environmental impact and restore natural systems. The goal, actually, is to make this the new standard practice for all businesses and cities by twenty twenty five.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The SBTN, which comprises leading environmental institutions and NGOs, will set specific, achievable goals for companies and eventually cities, helping them to reduce their environmental impact and start to restore natural systems. ... The goal is to make adoption of such objectives the new standard practice for all businesses and cities by 2025.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, 2025 is not that far off! And they're also aiming for, like, a mass mobilization of 100 million 'planetary stewards'?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, twenty twenty five is not that far off! And they're also aiming for, like, a mass mobilization of one hundred million planetary stewards?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Working through diverse media outlets to drive a broad-based cultural shift, we hope to foster a mass mobilization of some 100 million planetary stewards around the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. People pushing for action at all levels. I mean, it's a huge undertaking, but it's turning what feels like an impending crisis into, you know, an opportunity. Which is, like, a really positive spin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. People pushing for action at all levels. I mean, it's a huge undertaking, but it's turning what feels like an impending crisis into, you know, an opportunity. Which is, like, a really positive spin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now is the time to turn the impending crisis of the global commons into an opportunity for us all.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. I think that's a great note to end on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. I think that's a great note to end on.
